Description: Glazed composition scaraboid or seal in the shape of a round cone; circular base bearing boldly and deeply carved hieroglyphic inscription with Maat feather to left, sun-disc and men-draughtboard sign and bar underneath to right; pierced through diameter near the apex of cone; very smooth surface; greenish yellow glaze; in heavy and dense paste, yellow in colour, visible at break; slightly chipped.
Curator's comments: The inscription on this seal is an imitation of the prenomen of Amenhotep III and Seti I, Men-Maat-Ra. It could be understood as a motto, a prophylactic inscription or it could be a way to write the name of Amun-Ra, with the sign j replaced by a Maat feather (Hall 1913, 206, no. 2051; see also on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957). Similar cone seals were discovered on Punic sites such as Carthage (Gorton 1996, 48, fig. 8, no. 23-24, type XVB). According to Gorton, such scaraboids belongs to a Phoenician type of the 7th-6th centuries (Gorton 1996, 43, 48, type XVB). An almost identical conical seal was discovered in Naukratis: BM 1888,0601.60. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hall, H.R. 1913, Catalogue of Egyptian Scarabs, etc., in the British Museum, Vol. I Royal Scarabs, London, 206, no. 2051.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.095) (phase 3)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Commitee of)
